  1133. I purchased this product on October 24, 2014 and honestly could not be happier with the results.<br /><br />I have a long beard (relatively, about six inches from chin to tip). It's thick and the sides can be extremely unruly. Like most beardsmen (and anyone who knows a little bit about hair at all), I do not wash my beard every day, as doing so strips it of all of the natural oils which can lead to a dry, wiry, and coarse beard, which nobody wants. However, my face under the beard is prone to become extremely dry and even painful after a day of not washing it. The dandruff that would come out of my beard by the second day would rival Buffalo, NY's snow storms. Hence my reason for purchasing this particular beard balm. No beard oil I have ever purchased did anything to subdue the terribly itchy, dry, flaky skin under my magnificent face fur. I would even get particular patches on my chin where I could almost peel the dry skin off in one big piece. Gross, I know, but bear with me.<br /><br />I have been using the Honest Amish beard balm for almost a month now and the difference is incredible.Though the flaky skin has not been entirely eliminated, my face is not itchy, or painful at all. The dry patch I spoke of before is totally gone. For the sake of testing, I have gone an entire week without washing my beard and only using the beard balm. The flaky skin never got any worse. It's very mild and extremely manageable with just a bit of brushing. So, in short, this balm has helped my dry and flaky chin skin significantly.<br /><br />As I've said before, my beard is naturally soft. But with this beard balm, it's nearly as soft as the hair on my head, which is just remarkable. There's basically no difference in softness if I run my hand from the side of my head, down my sideburns, into my beard.<br /><br />Lastly, to address the previous issues with the smell and feel. The first time I used it, I used way too much and my beard was greasy. However, I discovered that for mysize of beard, I need less than a fingertip's worth of balm to work through and condition my entire beard. A little goes a very long way. When using just the amount I need, there is no greasy feel. Also, it helps to actually massage it in, as per the instructions. The beard absorbs the balm very well. And for the smell, it does not smell like licorice. I suppose to the untrained nose with no other reference to go by, licorice could be the most accurate description, but I assure you, anise is not the primary smell. It smells wonderful and it wears off after awhile (or perhaps my nose just gets used to it). It's more of a woodsy, slightly smoky smell with a hint of anise, if anything at all. I rather enjoy it.<br /><br />So, I will continue buying this product as long as I have a beard (or, forever). I highly recommend this to anyone who is looking for a better product for their beard and for a solution to dry skin. This stuff is the full monty, worth every penny. Do not hesitate to make the purchase. For you, and for your beard.

  1180. So after I opened the can of &#34;balm&#34; that turned out to be liquid oil that spilled on the front of my shirt, I noticed a pink slip of paper inside the bag the &#34;balm&#34; came in. Now the &#34;balm&#34; has granules in it and is not smooth at all. It is hard to apply and I have to comb the granules out after each use but does keep my woolly beard from being too woolly.   1183. There are good things to put in your beard, and there is this. Does my beard feel softer? Absolutely. Is my beard shinier than it was before? No doubt. Does the shine come at a cost? Yes. The first issue is the 'balm'. It's just oily. They put a lot of oils in it, so go figure. I expect a conditioner I put in my beard to be absorbed by my beard, not fun all day. It's a good thing I carry a handkerchief, because I'm going to need it with this product all day long. I even tried wiping it off my beard, no luck. This is a concern because what man doesn't stroke his beard? You can't not touch your beard. When you think real hard, when you think real soft, and even when you're not thinking at all! Secondary to me stroking my beard is a significant other being touched by my beard when I give them a kiss and leaving them with greasy skin. That's a sure way to get me sent to the shower to clean it off. At 80 degrees this is a liquid that has a thinner consistency than honey at the same temperature. Since I keep my honey at room temperature, I can make this comparison. I suppose it could use a higher beeswax content. I have Firehouse Moustache Wax, live in the high desert, and that stays fairly firm even though I keep it in my pocket all day during the summer. The smell. Some people have likened it to Anice (Licorice). That was my first impression. Until about 10 minutes later. Now it smells like the fish cleaning table at the lake. Not rotten, not rancid, just like fresh fish out of the lake being cleaned and gutted. It's not a terribly bad smell, I enjoy fishing, but it's not a smell I want to follow me for the first hour or two of my day. So, it's too greasy for a conditioner (I expected more of a lotion than an oil), and the smell is just unpleasant. If the choice is between the smell of beeswax and licorice, please choose to make your product not smell like licorice.
  1184. Works great and keeps beard soft and shinny !
  1185. This is AWESOME! Just began growing another beard bout one month ago, this conditioner smells great and really prevents the intense itching that has stopped me before! This balm will enable me to grow the beard I've always wanted!!!
  1186. Honest Amish Beard Balm is a good beard care product. I have been using it for about 2 months, 3 times a week. It has a decent smell that I would describe as pleasant and leaning toward a cocoa butter flavor. My beard is about 2\\" long, coarse and tangly. When I apply Amish Balm it does a noticeable good job in smoothing out my beard and allowing my beard comb to pass through nicely. It also helps me mold my beard into more of a V-shape rather then a fat H-shape.<br /><br />However, I don't think I will buy this product again for a couple of reasons. First, when it arrived it had a completely different chemistry then it does today. When I first opened the container the oil had separated from the cream which gave the product the consistency of grits. I'm not sure if this is how it was meant to be but in that form it was gross to look at, gross to touch and the oils dripped down my fingers like melted butter. Over time, the formula has congealed into the more common \\"wax\\" form that you see in their other products. It is much nicer to look at and apply when it is solid like this. Second, in either form (oil or solid) the product will coat your fingers and washing does not really get it off right away. I'm sure it is good for your hands but it is still pretty messy. Also, once you have it on your fingers and get any on the container, it is IMPOSSIBLE to open the container again because it is so slippery. The packaging could of used a little more thought put in.<br /><br />In conclusion, I like Amish Beard Balm pretty good but its changing chemistry and messiness will most likely keep me from buying it again. The frustration at trying to manipulate the container when your hands are slippery from applying the balm is also a lower rung reason why I would reconsider my purchase. Although it does not smell bad, it does not smell AWESOME either. And you could probably achieve the same results with a good store bought conditioner (with a smell you really like) without the messiness.ness.

  1209. Works great, I notice a big difference in the smoothness and softness in my beard when I use this balm.<br /><br />Be sure to read the instructions, as you may need to remelt the conditioner if the oils have separated. I found the easiest way to be to ...<br /><br />A. Boil some water.<br />B. Place the tin in a shallow bowl.<br />C. Pour the boiling water in the bowl up to the height of the lid of the tin.<br />D. Wait a few minutes, then use a tooth pick or a skewer to stir up the oils<br />E. Allow the balm to dry.<br /><br />I've only had to do this two times in the few months that I've had this product.
  1210. Shipped quick and container tells you to be careful because it may have turned into a liquid state if it was too hot. The third day it went somewhat bumpy, sort of like beads. The 4th day the product became unusable and left little ball like piece everywhere in my beard. I ended up just washing it out. So unless you have a hotplate on your vanity to set this on I would stay away. Also I live in Arizona and I never have my house below 72 degrees so for it to separate like it does is strange.

  1252. I had my doubts about this, only because of the price. But I bought it based on the great reviews. I was even more doubtful when it arrived and the can is much smaller than the picture appears. only about 2.5 inches around.<br /><br />I was looking for something to quell the dreaded 'new beard itch'. I was at my wits end, ready to shave off another fledgling beard because it was irritating my face something terrible. I'm talking red skin, and wanting to scratch my face off itchy. I ordered, and toughed out the two days with witch hazel and various other general purpose lotions that just weren't doing the trick.<br /><br />The day after using this product, complete beard comfort! Hallelujah!<br /><br />Definitely read the directions, it takes a little getting used to. A _very_ small amount is plenty, just enough to cover a fingertip. Put it in your palm to 'melt', and then apply, preferably after a shower. It comes out of the can as sort of soft sandy texture, and you get it good and melty in your palms, and then rub in. Great mild licorice smell, absorbs in fully, no greasy beard feel at all. I would say this is more for beard/skin conditioning, with a minimum amount of corralling wild hairs.<br /><br />So while expensive, it works like magic, beard looks and smells great, and you use so little it should last a good long while.

  1281. This stuff is amazing.<br /><br />I have always been able to grow a thick beard, and having spent 6 years in the military, I was never able to see it come to full fruition. Once I got out, I started trying to grow my beard as thick and full as I could, but my skin became extremely irritated underneath. Huge red spots of dry, irritated skin would thrive under the thick whiskers, and I would have to itch all over my face like crazy, especially the upper lip area in my mustache. With visible flakes being embarrassing aside from the discomfort, I would always keep it relatively short so I could get moisturizer to the skin relatively easily.<br /><br />Last year my friends and I started a friendly competition and I was hoping my skin would have matured or changed, but sadly, this was not the case. This year, I started researching ways to help me maintain a pristine and full beard, while avoiding the itchiness, and came across this product as a result of reviews here on Amazon.<br /><br />It's like rubbing lukewarm oily butter on your face, that's the consistency I can most closely compare it to, but man does it work! I love the smell; it smells like peppermint pine. You'll know what I mean when you smell it.<br /><br />Going 3 months strong and there is not one flake and I do not itch in the slightest. Whatever, it's what's inside that counts, right? Well, the lid to the mustache was was so tight I ended up leaving it barely attached so I wouldn't have to fight with it. For the balm, the &#34;wet sand&#34; meets tapioca pudding consistency was interesting if not weird. It makes a creamy oil when warmed up in your hands and leaves your beard pretty oily throughout the day and builds up even more so during a week of use unless you shampoo your beard daily. I didn't enjoy the scent or product very much but I thought maybe the earthiness scent would translate to manliness. It was when my 8 daughter would turn her nose up at kisses saying my beard smelled like vomit that I realized this product had to go. The mustache wax that was a pain to apply had to go as well. I switched over to Beard Brand for beard oil and mustache wax and realized caring for your facial can be downright pleasurable for you and your loved ones. Their scents are great, the oil is light and easy to apply, and the mustache wax is light and soft and comes in an applicator similar to chapstick that can run across the `stache and eyebrows easily. I gave Honest Amish an honest month of use and honestly can say I this product was objectionable for me and my family.

I feel as though it can sometimes make my face shine a bit, and I'm using have a fingertips worth.   1400. I'm almost 40 and have never had more than a 3 day growth of facial hair. You see, genetics were not nice to me. Most of my family are either Irish, Italian or Samoan. Most of my traits are more common with the Italian and Samoan sides of my family. This means all of my hair is unruly. I also do shave my head so shaving my face is just a natural swipe down from the head, but I decided to give the beard a try. First week, there was a tremendous amount of growth. Everyone loved it. It itched. My flesh under the beard, that was visible, was red. I'm guessing I can thank my Irish skin for that. The beard itself was fairly soft to the touch, but it was very irritated. I picked up some Organix conditioner that is supposed to be good to use a couple times a week for washing the beard. That helped some, but not enough.<br /><br />Then I saw this product and decided it's worth the try. Maybe I'm wrong, but there's a lot of talk in the reviews about the scent. As someone who has shaved my head for 20 years, the scent to me is not much different than Bay Rum. I've ran out of my favorite shave soap before and had to fall back on bay rum scented shave soap. It's very similar to this scent. Which means I'm not particularly fond of it, but it's not bad.<br /><br />The good news is, after using this beard balm for a week, all of the redness is gone and so is the itching. I've found out from an older bearded man whom I work with that it's not really &#34;itching&#34;, it's more my hands wanting to pull at the beard. I'm also not for sure if I'm using it the way most do. I simply pinch a little bit out, wet my hands and rub my hands together. Then rub it into the beard in a circular motion. It feels really nice. It instantly caused the irritation to cool and took away the itchy feeling. If anyone is wondering about the texture, it's sort of grainy. It feels like something that is good for your skin. By rubbing it in my hands it has even softened my hands. That's a pretty big deal since I use heavy machinery outdoors and have rough, calloused hands. You can look at that as relative to what it does for your face/beard. As of today, I'm 14 days without shaving my face and have a nice beard that feels clean and healthy. That's exactly what I wanted from this product and it has succeeded.<br /><br />My apologies to my fellow bearded brethren reviewers for not believing it worked as good as they said.ce I use heavy machinery outdoors and have rough, calloused hands. You can look at that as relative to what it does for your face/beard. As of today, I'm 14 days without shaving my face and have a nice beard that feels clean and healthy. That's exactly what I wanted from this product and it has succeeded.<br /><br />My apologies to my fellow bearded brethren reviewers for not believing it worked as good as they said.

  1447. I'm new to the beard game. Simply because my previous employers didn't allow them. I purchased this based off all the 4-5 stars it got. The described scent had me interested. I love the smell. It has a licorice hint along with subtle notes of nut/woods (to me). It's pretty simple and straight forward to apply. Put a little bit into your balm, rub and work around until it melts into a oil type substance on your hands and work in into your beard. Pretty simple.<br /><br />A close friend of mine loved the smell, she encouraged I strictly use this only from now on. After I apply it, I like to comb my beard. It provides a nice shine, which brings out your highlights. Definitely worth the buy.

It's not totally scent free but I like the smell and it goes away after a few hours. It's kind of a cross between vanilla and cloves which is relaxing. I'm also allergic to a bunch of spices, nuts and fragrances and this doesn't bother me or irritate my skin. I highly recommend this.

At the weekends it needs a little gardening to remove the small rodents and nesting birds that moved in during the week. I use a bluebeard wash conditioner (which is awesome) and this stuff.<br /><br />It is like a clarified butter, which you rub between your palms to liquify. It becomes an oil in seconds. you rub in and it softens and adds a gloss to your beard. It has some control but if you need to tame your unruly man pelt you need to use the wax as well. I do not notice any smell good or bad from it.<br /><br />One last thought is is an oil so make sure an use a paper towel to dry off any skin that you have the balm on.<br /><br />Rumspringa!!!!

  1496. I like this stuff: it's got a nice smell (though my girlfriend doesn't love it), and it makes your beard smooth and shiny. It also helps with itching of facial hair.   1497. Simply regarding the concerns: Yes, it is a bit oily, but less is more. If you put 10 pumps of lotion on your hands, they'd be slimey too. It does have a scent, though it's much more complex than anise (way to go to all the savvy dudes who knew how to describe licorice); it smells like chai and cedar, which I find rather pleasant. The one thing that I did have some difficulties with on rare occasion is melting the product. You take a very small amount of the paste and rub it between your fingertips to make a liquid that's easy to apply. If your fingers are cold for some reason (say you just rinsed your toothbrush in cold water), this can be difficult. I employed a few solutions. One, simply putting some of the paste into my beard and allowing the heat from my face to melt it for dispersion worked fine, though this can leave one area bit concentrated. The easier solution, if you know your hands are cold, is to just run them in hot water for a few seconds.
  1498. I bought this for my husband for fathers day. I love the ingredients and the way it smells. I noticed a softening of his beard hairs rather quickly. Its a little expensive but will go a long way if you use the amount you are supposed too. I will be buying this again.

  1595. I have a full beard and at times it seems to have mind of it's own. A year or so ago I ordered Honest Amish Beard conditioner from Amazon. Along with it I ordered the Heavy Duty Beard Conditioner. I loved both. They make my beard softer and more manageable and it has a healthy sheen, almost a glisten. But the best part was the smell. It smelled like citrus, manly citrus, and was a nice refreshing scent that you got throughout the day. Best, my wife loved the fragrance too. When both of those were used up I ordered more of the regular beard conditioner. It appears to be the same stuff but there is no scent. None. To me, not having that citrus scent really diminishes the pleasure of using the product. Now it is just another product, a treatment rather than a treat. Don't know why they would take the scent out but I'm not sure I'll buy it again without the scent. If they put it back I'd give it five stars and buy some more.!

  1606. This is actually kind of a difficult product to review.<br /><br />To start, I bought this because I wanted a beard that wouldn't make my wife hate me. See, I like my beard. But my wife doesn't fancy kissing a hobo so I had to tame it.<br /><br />First thing to know is that this is NOT some kind of shaping or styling balm. It will NOT keep down unruly hairs or help you style a long bear. This product, at least for me, was purely about keeping my beard soft and pleasant for the wife.<br /><br />I think it does the job in that respect, but there are some things you need to know. While it may soften your beard, it will also make it a bit oily for a while. As someone who constantly plays with his beard, this kind of got me to stop doing that. I suppose that's a good thing. However, if you like running your hands through your chin forest, be advised they will come away like you've been cleaning up an oil spill.<br /><br />The product itself is quite easy to use and even Mungo Man could have figured it out.<br /><br />So, here's the hard part of the review; will YOU like the scent? I can't tell you. It's...unique. If you're the kind of guy who enjoys the smell of mud and greasy car parts or who inhales deeply the burning lawn debris of your neighbor, then you will probably like this stuff. If you wear cologne made by wealthy Frenchists or you get your hair cut once a week and shop for underwear in catalogs, then you probably won't. Is that vague and mildly offensive to some? Yeah, but it's the best way I can try to be helpful.<br /><br />My wife doesn't seem to even notice the smell and for me it's usually gone in 10 minutes after application so it's kind of a non- factor. Still, it seems to be a point of contention among the reviewers here. I don't think anyone will be able to tell you whether you will like it or not. You'll just have to take the risk. Scent aside, this is a pretty good product for the money.<br /><br />I knocked off a star because it hasn't made my beard as soft as I would like since I started using it. Since I don't have a control beard growing somewhere else on my body, I don't know what it would feel like if I weren't using the stuff, though.asn't made my beard as soft as I would like since I started using it. Since I don't have a control beard growing somewhere else on my body, I don't know what it would feel like if I weren't using the stuff, though.

  1620. Been using for a week now and am pleased. But anyone out there who has neglected their beard or just shampoos and conditions it will probably see huge improvements.<br /><br />The Good-<br />Works well to condition my beard and skin.<br />Works well to keep my beard hairs in check.<br />Is a suitable replacement for my families home made balm that my grand parents made (Trust me that is a huge complement from me)<br /><br />The less than Good.<br />A lot of people have commented on the smell of this balm. Some love it, others don't mind it, I nearly hate it! The good news is that I am going to make it REALLY simple for you to decide whether you will like it or not! Go to the store and buy a bag of black licorice and smell it. It's THAT simple! It smells EXACTLY like that. I don't much like licorice, and I hate the smell. Since this balm is sitting under my nose it makes me very self conscious for about an hour till the scent luckily dies down and nearly vanishes. This however I won't hold against them as they DO sell an unscented one.<br /><br />Other thing I don't like. A weird cross promotion with Duck Dynasty makes me take this otherwise great brand slightly less seriously.

  1626. First, do not use too much if you have a short beard. My beard is not that long, a good 4 1/2 inches, and I only use the back of my thumb nail for measuring the amount. Next, it is kind of gresy, but not a whole lot. Like I said, the longer the more you'll need; if shorter like mine, just the back of your nail is fine. It is grainy but not that kind of grainy that you have to rub and rub to disappear. In less than 5 seconds, the grains will disappear as soon as it gets warm. It doesn't have a strong hold but will straighten out rogue hairs (I have a few). Once straighten, they pretty much stay like that while being soft and no greasy or heavy feeling to it. I noticed that If I keep combing it all day the hairs stay straighten, so keep that in mind. MOST IMPORTANTLY, The SCENT. One reviewer described it as \\"in the middle\\" and I have to agree. When first applying it, it smells kind of strong. But it goes away after maybe 20 -30 minutes, maybe sooner. Then , you can barely smell it, if at all. I think if you can manage it the first few minutes after applying it, I think you'll like it. Plus, I love that it's a nice quantity. The tin is pretty big compared to two other balms I've tried. Ultimately, I like it plain and simple. Like other researchers, I hope this helps. #Keepbearding
  1627. It's amazing. My beard is so soft. I touch it all day lol.

The picture makes it look like a large can of shoe polish, but it's really tiny for the price.   1695. I've sported a short beard on and off for the last several years. I had the consistent problem of my chin becoming unbearably itchy every time I let the beard grow past a certain length. After some research online I was led to beard balms and eventually to Honest Amish. From the first time I applied it, the itching issue disappeared. Simply melt the wax between your palms and apply. The balm will keep your beard and more importantly, the skin underneath well hydrated. While some other reviews have complained about the smell, I find it mildly pleasant and it's generally extremely light unless you apply a lot of the balm. It will cause your beard to become somewhat oily, depending on how much you use. It will rub off on your hands if you run them through your beard, even hours later. It does give some extremely light hold, but on &#34;bad beard days&#34; I've found that it's not up to the task of taming stray hairs. 4 stars only because of the lack of any hold. All in all, a great product.
  1696. One can has lasted me 3 months, it is oily on the hands after application, but it truly stops beard dander and itchy face. The trick is to use just enough and apply long past after you think you used up on your fingers. The smell is nice, kind of seasonal like fresh cloves and honey. Apply in the morning or it might grease up your pillow.
  1697. Not a good smell, just personally dislike the smell.

  1703. I never have had an issue with scented oils, cologne, or anything else I put on my body/face. But after applying this to my beard I immediately had an outburst of allergy reactions in my nose and I've since been fighting a high irritable sense of smell that causes my nose to run and symptoms of a cold running down into my throat. It turns out I am allergic to this beard balm because the scent is too strong for me. I reapplied it after waiting 5 days of non-use and sure enough my nose started reacting heavily to the scent again. I definitely cannot use this product. Note, this product did NOT irritate my skin.<br /><br />I for one am not happy with the smell. Smells like a hippy + licorice and is not pleasant for someone that wants to smell nice to colleagues in the office. Strangely I like the smell of licorice but something isn't right with this scent. It's quite obvious to people near you where the smell is coming from, and overall I do not think it is very pleasant. My girlfiend does not like it. Nor do any other girls I've asked.<br /><br />As for the natural conditioning properties it has... I'm sure it works well and can soften your beard, it's easy to apply and adds a bit of shine to the beard. But after using this product for a short while I don't feel any better and realize that a freshly washed and groomed beard is better than a pungent hippie beard.

  1751. I'm going to try to address several issues that repeatedly come up in reviews of this product:<br /><br />1) The tin that this product comes in is very small. I find it a little hard to justify the price versus the quantity of what is essentially wax.<br /><br />2) The wax base has microbeads in it. This bothers some people, but I found it a non-issue. The beads probably serve to facilitate the melting process when rubbing the hands together before applying the product.<br /><br />3) The smell. I am not sure what some people are smelling. I have heard it referred to as an overpowering black licorice (anise) scent. I did not have this experience, myself. I found the scent to be nothing offensive at all. Not overpowering in any way.<br /><br />4) People saying it helps to grow a thicker / longer beard. This is complete nonsense. I don't think the manufacturers ever state this in their advertising, but some people have been putting this out there. Genetics is the main determiner of your beard growth pattern, not wax.<br /><br />5) My own personal overall impression ... middle of the road. I don't hate it, but I don't love it. I'm not sure that it does anything terribly beneficial. My beard is perhaps a little softer, but the effect is short-lived. I generally use normal hair conditioner on my beard once or twice a week and get the same benefit at a much better cost per application over this product. It just seems a little expensive for what you actually get.<br /><br />I'll keep an open mind and reserve the right to alter my review in case further experience changes my perceptions.

I trimmed my beard short before I started applying the balm, hoping that when it reached its earlier length and density that I'd notice any improvement. Weeks later, I have not.<br /><br />After repeatedly applying the product as instructed (by taking a small dab and melting it between your hands, then rubbing it through your beard) I noticed one thing immediately: despite applying it as an oily liquid, it would dry in minutes and create ugly flakes in my beard that I would then have to wash out - effectively nullifying it as a \\"leave-in\\" conditioner. The mealy, oily texture I could forgive, but not the flakes.<br /><br />As far as I can tell the balm doesn't even achieve its primary purpose of being a conditioner - beard is still course and wiry, only now with flakes of balm residue to rinse out. At best this product is wildly inconsistent and only ships usable balm some of the time, at worst all it leaves you with is a greasy, flaky beard and a $15 hole in your wallet. I doubt I'll finish the tin I purchased.

  1820. First let me say that I enjoy the scent of the product and that it does a good job conditioning my beard.<br /><br />The problem that I had with this product is that it turns to soup in the container at a rather low temperature. I live in southern California, and when I first received the product, it included a warning about the products consistency due to shipping temperatures which made perfect sense to me. I went ahead and opened it to take a peek, and it was liquid, not unlike melted butter. &#34;No problem&#34;, I thought to myself, &#34;I'll just put this in the fridge for a bit to let it firm up and that should be the end of it.&#34; I pulled it out of the fridge later and looked at the product again and it looked exactly as I expected it to, so I placed it in my bathroom. Unfortunately my bathroom is directly hit by the afternoon sun, so on the afternoon I first tried the product, it was soup again. So now I keep it in the coolest room in my house which maintains it at a usable consistency. However, during the cooling process the ingredients that have a higher melting point congeal together first which requires me to work it a little longer on my beard to get the little wax beads to melt.<br /><br />It still works great and smells good, but the products consistency is a little off putting to me.
  1821. It works really well, I'm just not so sure about it's scent...

  1823. First I have to mention how fast the product got to me in my current APO location. 8 days (including the weekend)! That's simply amazing. I'm still waiting on products I've ordered from other vendors from 2.5 weeks ago. Nice work Honest Amish!<br /><br />Never tried anything like this before. Wish I had known about it the last couple of times I grew my beard out.<br /><br />Still experimenting with the quantity that I use per application. Even if I have to order more I won't be upset in the slightest!<br /><br />I have a naturally wirey beard with a defiant personality. This balm allows me to train my beard in the direction I want it to flow and keeps those defiant hairs in line with the other. Not to mention that it doesn't feel brittle anymore but closer to 'top of the head' type hair. The occassional itch seems to be repressed as well.<br /><br />Another bonus is that with this stuff in my beard, the red (I have auburn color hair) doesn't just stand out, it explodes in the sun light and has completely caught some people off guard. Guess I don't look like a natural red head.<br /><br />After the application, it rinses easily and clean from the hands. Smells great too.
  1824. Smells great, feels great, beard looks great.
  1825. Tin arrived dented and I was not impressed by the smell.
  1826. Good stuff came a bit grainy but dissolves as you rub palms together.
  1827. Honest Amish was the first beard balm I used when I started my beard several months ago. I've since tried two or three other beard conditioners, but keep going back to the Honest Amish. I will only use Honest Amish Beard Balm from now on.
  1828. To put it bluntly, this mess be like some type of BEARD CRACK, yo.<br /><br />My beard used to be scraggly and coarse, like an old sailor's big toenail. Now it is smooth to the touch, exudes a rich but not overpowering scent of majestic herbs and lavish oils while flaunting a sumptuous shine to complete the mesmerizing trifecta of beard splendor that falls just short of hypnotizing any whose gaze may fall upon it.<br /><br />I get stopped on the street, ogled on the train and put in precarious situations by the opposite sex more often than not (to my wife's vexation).<br /><br />I just got a raise, which I'd be dishonest if I said was as a result of my strong work ethic and lack of tardiness. My wife recently became pregnant after 8 months of unsuccessful (yet relentless) attempts at procreation. Coincidence? Well let's just say I've injected some Amish names onto the baby name list for good measure (Briskey and Whetstone are frontrunners, no doubt).<br /><br />In closing, people don't judge a man by his achievements, they judge him by his beard. When opportunity strikes, make sure you've spent the 4 minutes it takes to give you a leg up above the competition and lather that sweet victory in to every follicle.

After the second time I used it (the second being the only time I used it properly) my wife commented that my beard feels softer and I agree. The smell of the product goes away in a few hours and if used sparingly it isn't greasy nor oily in my beard but my hands could use a good rubbing on dry skin or a wipe with a paper towel.<br /><br />Overall I like the product a lot but I don't care much for the price which leads me to look for cheaper alternatives or making my own in large batches.

  1865. This stuff is great. I have chronically dry skin, and my beard was visibly flaky (especially in my mustache and chin area). My skin was getting very irritated from rubbing my beard to get rid of the big flakes. I love my beard, have had it for over 1 year, but it was getting to the point that I was fed up enough to consider shaving it off. Then I bought the Honest Amish Beard Balm, which almost immediately made it better. I really only use it around once per week and I no longer have the visible flakiness and my skin is not irritated at all. I would recommend this to any bearded folks with dry skin.<br /><br />My only very minor gripe, is that I am not crazy about the smell. Because it is 100% natural, it doesn't have any aroma's added. The first time I used it, I kept on getting whiffs of a waxy black licorice type aroma... and I HATE black licorice. But I really don't even notice it anymore.<br /><br />If you are on the fence, just try it. From the product description, it is apparent that the manufacturers stand behind their product and will accept returns for unsatisfied customers (as long as at least 50% of the product is left). No risk.
  1866. I use this everyday. My beard and face are happier for it.

  1868. Love it! I use it daily. I switched to balm from oil when my beard got beyond 3 inches because balm makes it much easier to manage and work-in with a comb. I love the smell, it has undertones of clove with is almost therapeutic. They don't list their ingredients (and I don't blame them), but I'm willing to bet it's a shea butter base (but I'm only guessing here). Bottom line, it's great stuff! I've been using it for about a month, daily and my beard is so soft and shiny, while not greasy. It's great stuff and I would definitely recommend it.<br /><br />Oh yea, the 2 ounces last a lot longer than you would imagine. To apply it, put a bit on your finger tip. Rub it together in-between your palms until it's nice and thin... then rub it all over your beard, even down to your skin. Then take a comb and use the tight side of the comb to gently comb your beard (while combing, make sure you can feel the comb gently raking the skin of your face... this will get the conditioner deep into your beard and close to your skin).

He has also been able to grow his beard much longer with this balm since it keeps a good level of moisture in the hair and prevents breakage. Didn't have the issue of grittiness that some have commented on, just have to warm it up in your hands before applying.   1891. Looking for a quick easy way to condition your beard? Look no further. Any man with a beard should consider this. You can, and I do, put a couple of drops of something like Essential Oils into your hands and rub it in after you apply the Honest Amish to give a different scent. Choose wisely your scent. I use this by itself daily and it really keeps my beard nice, controls split ends and gives a nice shine especially when outdoors.   1892. It took a few months for me to really fall in love with this balm. What I discovered is less is more. I was using too much and it was leaving my beard feeling greasy. It goes away in a few minutes after applying, but it's definitely there. When I asked my wife what she thought it smelled like, she described it as &#34;sexy lumberjack&#34; and &#34;testosterone and manliness.&#34; If I were to kill a bear and fell a tree with my pocketknife and then combine the oils of both and use them on my beard, that's how this stuff smells. Some say it smells like black licorice, but that's misleading. I can see why they describe it that way, but I hate the smell of black licorice and I really like the smell of this stuff. Each time I put it on, I feel like I should cook a steak and then go kill ISIS bastards in the Middle East.

  1935. I've been using this stuff for 3 months now (still on can number 1), and I love it. I firmly believe if one is to grow a beard or any Length of facial hair, Honest Amish Balm is the way to go. It solves the problem of &#34;beardruff,&#34; and it prevents split ends in a beard. The licorice smell was not my favorite at first, but it really is mild and light and fades as the hours pass. Now I don't even notice it. I actually use another scented oil at times to enhance or synergize the fragrance. I'm applying this balm every 12 hours or 2 times in a day with great results. I receive complements every day on how well I keep up the beard, and how soft it has become. Thumbs up for this product!
  1936. Spoiler....this is from a woman's pont of view. I ordered this for my husband. THIS STUFF IS AMAZING! After one application his beard was softer and more manageable. After three days, the difference is tremendous. I just ordered some for my brother in law. Very happy with this purchase.
  1937. I have never written a review for anything on amazon, or anywhere else.<br />BUT I had to come back and comment on this product.. because it is just so darn good!<br /><br />I bought this stuff last week, and received it on Friday. I have used it twice. Within minutes of first application, the difference was ENORMOUS. Softer, easier to brush, staying in place, and cut down on 'loose' hairs sticking up everywhere.<br /><br />I have discussed this product with a few friends who were put off by the possible 'scent' of the product. I would NOT let that stop you, as the scent is very subtle and pleasant. Certainly beats stinkbeard :)<br /><br />Application is easy, put a little of the product in the palm of your hands, rub together until the thick waxy product turns into an oil, then rub into beard.<br /><br />If you have never tried a beard product before, i cannot recommend this Honest Amish beard balm enough!<br /><br />Your beard, and anyone who loves it, will appreciate the small effort it takes to take it from hobo to Gandalf
  1938. This is the first time I have purchased this product and I’m very happy it. As for the cost being a little expensive, I was happy to see that it is made here in the USA. What was on one of the pieces of paper that came with the conditioner “made by hand in the U.S.A. for an honest wage” is very important to me to support my fellow Americans, and getting a good product.

  1941. smells so good! keeps my face bush feeling really soft. also, I love the packaging and tin that it comes in.
  1942. I've really enjoyed using this leave-in conditioner. I've been using it for a few months now and I can tell my beard is a lot healthier - it looks fuller & feels softer. Previously, I've used &#34;Wild Man Beard Oil&#34; which was good but definitely didn't improve the health of my beard. So, if you've got some split ends in your beard & it feels more wiry than soft, think about using this stuff. The only negative thing I have to say about it is that I don't love the scent - it has a slight licorice smell to it; however, this is relatively minor considering how well the product works.
  1943. Softens my beard, makes it shine, and helps control unmanageable hairs. Great smell too. I respectfully disagree with other reviewers who have stated that the smell is overwhelming. It is a noticeable (but not overpowering) scent when first applied, but that wears off fairly quickly. My wife, who was skeptical, is now a believer in the product. Good stuff.

  1965. It arrived separated, so I put it next to my heated up over for a while to melt it, shook it up, and popped it I'm the fridge. No big deal, got it back to the way it should be. Seemed to absorb fast, and definitely made my beard softer.<br /><br />And now for the issue...the smell. People say it smells like black licorice and then goes away. I'll revise that to: it smells like anise, very strongly, and then faintly. My girlfriend hated the licorice smell, so this product lasted about three days for me.<br /><br />Loved the company's idea, great packaging, and you can tell they care about the product, which is awesome. But from a personal standpoint, I just can't go above three stats. I'll be trying the scent free beard oil drops (from Amazon) next!
  1966. Actually helped my spotty beard grow
  1967. Having no previous experience grooming a beard, I had high hopes but low expectations. I now have used several products from other vendors (almost all rather disappointing) and the following from Honest Amish: Beard Balm, Original Beard Wax and Heavy Duty Beard Balm. Each Honest Amish product has been really good in its own way. You will have to find the right combination for your beard.<br /><br />I had to experiment with how to use these products and learn by trial and error. My beard has shapes it doesn't want to give up and one area that is really like crinkled wires. My grooming now is to use the Heavy Duty Beard Balm after my shower, even if I used a conditioning shampoo. Then as I comb it, add just a tiny bit of the Original Beard Wax to the area of crinkled wires. For the first time in my life, my beard looks smart.<br /><br />Your experience will likely differ from mine, but by trial and error you will have as good an experience as mine, I suspect. It is only once I tried,these products that I've begun to understand how my great great grandfather groomed his beard 100 or more years ago.
  1968. This product is a little like putting a pat of butter in your hands, working it to liquid and putting it on your beard. It does make your beard shine and gives it a bit of softness, but it is a little too greasy for me. Even after being in your beard for several hours, it will leave a greasy film on anything your beard touches (hands, clothes, etc.). I was somewhat disappointed as I really like the Honest Amish Beard Wax: great stuff!
  1969. I am just beginning to grow my beard and this product is a real positive addition in the morning after my shower. I rub it onto the tip of my fingers and the product turns into a very comfortable oil. It applies easily and feels good too!
  1970. I just started growing a beard and this product came recommended from a friend. So far it's working great! It makes my beard softer and only has a slight scent to it. You only need a small amount in the palm of your hand that you rub together until the product become liquefied and then you rub onto your beard. That's it...that simple. I haven't found a better beard product.
  1971. It seemed to be working but i couldn't handle the smell. It had a unique smell and I couldn't take it and neither could my wife. If you can tolerate the smell you it may work when used for an extended period of time.
  1972. It smells kinda funky but the smell wears off fairly quickly. Works well on my beard controlling the random hairs, especially the mustache ones that flip up and tickle my nose! haha
  1973. Nice product. The scent is great and it is easy to use. Just put a little on your hands, rub together until melted then apply to beard and work down to skin. I immediately felt my skin tingle. My beard is starting to feel softer after using balm 3 or 4 times. I purchased more right away - the &#34;heavy duty&#34; version this time to see if there is a big difference..
  1974. I started using this oil daily to see if my beard would begin to soften up, and after 2 months my beard doesn't feel much softer than before, the exception to this being if the oil is still in my beard. It makes my wife very unhappy when I kiss her and she gets a nice dab of oily residue on her face & I was hoping it would dry a bit faster. It does at least smell very nice but I can’t honestly recommend this product based on the price, quantity and lasting effect (or lack thereof). The oil seems to be a bit strong, many have said this oil is also good for the skin and sooths irritation, and while I didn’t have any problems it did burn a bit if it got anywhere near my eyes. My suggestion is to look for another brand as this one seems to be either hit or miss.
  1975. Superb balm keeps my beard healthy and attractive. I love the pleasant smell.
  1976. Makes your beard soft and shiny.... a little goes a long way.
  1977. Love what it does to the beard. No frizz at all.
